docs.snippet: LEAD: The leading trading nations have flashed a green light for final bargaining in the postwar period's eighth and most ambitious set of talks to lower trade barriers.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The leading trading nations have flashed a green light for final bargaining in the postwar period's eighth and most ambitious set of talks to lower trade barriers.

headline.main: Talks on Trade Enter Final Bargaining Stage

keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: Carla A. Hills keeps a crowbar in a picture frame in the anteroom of her office two blocks from the White House. It is a handy symbol of the toughness she wants to project as the chief battler against foreign trade barriers.

headline.main: New U.S. Trade Chief Is Set to Use a Big Stick Against Any Barriers

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: Uruguayans will vote Sunday on whether to prosecute military men for political killings and torture committed during a counterinsurgency drive nearly 20 years ago.

byline.original: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: To the Editor: Traveling through Argentina and Uruguay recently, my family and I came across a problem worth noting: Traveler's checks do not carry much weight in that part of the world. We received varied and sundry explanations from bank...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: To the Editor: Traveling through Argentina and Uruguay recently, my family and I came across a problem worth noting: Traveler's checks do not carry much weight in that part of the world. We received varied and sundry explanations from bank clerks and foreign exchange booths ranging from cash-only policies to ''Sorry, we can't help you.

docs.snippet: LEAD: Uruguyans voted today to reject an effort to overturn the amnesty granted the armed forces for political crimes committed in the 1960's and 1970's, according to projections from official returns.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Uruguyans voted today to reject an effort to overturn the amnesty granted the armed forces for political crimes committed in the 1960's and 1970's, according to projections from official returns.

headline.main: Uruguay Votes to Retain Amnesty for the Military

byline.original: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD:  Uruguay Votes on Amnesty  Uruguayans voted on whether to retain the amnesty granted to the armed forces for political crimes of the 1960's and 1970's. Page A6.  Touring Pros of the Piano  The 40 young men and women at the Van Cliburn...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Uruguay Votes on Amnesty Uruguayans voted on whether to retain the amnesty granted to the armed forces for political crimes of the 1960's and 1970's. Page A6. Touring Pros of the Piano The 40 young men and women at the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition next month will be competing with familiar rivals.
docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.snippet: LEAD: As it became clear that opponents of the amnesty granted to the military for political crimes had failed to overturn it in a referendum on Sunday, two middle-aged former guerrillas paid a visit to a Senator and Cabinet minister.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: As it became clear that opponents of the amnesty granted to the military for political crimes had failed to overturn it in a referendum on Sunday, two middle-aged former guerrillas paid a visit to a Senator and Cabinet minister.

headline.main: In Uruguay, a Vote for Forgiveness

byline.original: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: It's always hard for a nation to sit in judgment on itself - especially if those being judged are armed and uniformed. Remarkably, a quarter of Uruguay's electorate forced a referendum on whether to try military officers for abuses between 1973...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: It's always hard for a nation to sit in judgment on itself - especially if those being judged are armed and uniformed. Remarkably, a quarter of Uruguay's electorate forced a referendum on whether to try military officers for abuses between 1973 and 1985, when 50,000 people were jailed in a nation of three million.
